title: 112_s2046
content: The Act is titled the "Visa Waiver Program Enhanced Security and Reform Act." It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The "Visa Waiver Program Enhanced Security and Reform Act" amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to give the Secretary of Homeland Security the authority to designate countries as program countries if they meet specific requirements. The term "appropriate congressional committees" is defined in the Act. The "Visa Waiver Program Enhanced Security and Reform Act" allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to designate countries for the program based on specific criteria. The term "appropriate congressional committees" includes committees from both the Senate and the House of Representatives. The term "overstay rate" is defined as the ratio of overstays to total visitors for countries being considered for program designation. The curr_chunk discusses the number of nationals from a specific country who overstayed their nonimmigrant visas in the United States. The curr_chunk discusses the overstay rate of nationals from a specific country who were admitted to the United States on nonimmigrant visas. The curr_chunk provides data on nationals from a specific country who overstayed their authorized stay in the United States on nonimmigrant visas. The curr_chunk discusses the computation of overstay rates for nationals from a specific country whose authorized stay in the United States on nonimmigrant visas ended during a fiscal year. The Secretary of Homeland Security can use information from databases to ensure accuracy. The term "program country" refers to a country designated as such under subparagraph (A). The curr_chunk amends Section 217 of the Immigration and Nationality Act by changing references from "Attorney General" to "Secretary of Homeland Security" and updating committee references to "appropriate congressional committees." The curr_chunk amends Section 217 of the Immigration and Nationality Act by updating committee references to "appropriate congressional committees" and removing subsection (c)(7)(E). The curr_chunk amends Section 217 of the Immigration and Nationality Act by designating program countries based on overstay rates. The curr_chunk amends Section 217 of the Immigration and Nationality Act to set numerical limitations for nonimmigrant visa refusal and overstay rates for designated program countries. The curr_chunk further amends Section 217 of the Immigration and Nationality Act to establish qualification criteria for program countries and the process for continuing designation. The curr_chunk amends Section 217 of the Immigration and Nationality Act to address the computation of visa refusal rates and judicial review for program countries. The curr_chunk amends Section 217 of the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding visa refusal rates, judicial review, and waiver authority. The curr_chunk amends Section 217 of the Immigration and Nationality Act to grant waiver authority to the Secretary of Homeland Security for countries meeting specific security criteria. The curr_chunk discusses the criteria for countries to be designated as program countries, including a downward trend in visa refusals, cooperation on counterterrorism initiatives, and low visa refusal rates in the previous fiscal year. The curr_chunk states that the visa refusal rate for a country must not exceed 10 percent of the total number of nationals granted or refused nonimmigrant visas in the previous fiscal year. SEC. 4. TERMINATION OF DESIGNATION; PROBATION. Section 217(f) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include definitions for probationary period and program country. The Secretary of Homeland Security will determine probationary status and notify noncompliance during a program country's periodic evaluation. The Secretary of Homeland Security will determine if a program country complies with program requirements. If not, the country will be placed on probation for the following fiscal year. At the end of the probationary period, actions will be taken. At the end of the initial probationary period, the Secretary of Homeland Security will take action based on compliance with program requirements. Compliance may lead to the end of the country's probationary period, while noncompliance may result in further evaluation. If noncompliance with program requirements persists after the initial probationary period, the Secretary may terminate the country's participation or continue probation if deemed in the national interest. Actions will be taken at the end of additional probationary periods. At the end of additional probationary periods, the Secretary will either end the country's probationary status if in compliance with program requirements or terminate the country's participation if noncompliant. The program country remains in non-compliance with program requirements, leading to termination of participation in the program. Termination takes effect at the start of the following fiscal year, with nationals remaining eligible for a waiver until then. After termination, nationals of the country are subject to specific treatment. Terminated nationals remain eligible for a waiver until termination takes effect. Waivers granted before termination are not invalidated. The Secretary of State plays a consultative role in the process. The Comptroller General of the United States will review the methods used by the Secretary of Homeland Security to track aliens entering and exiting the United States, as well as to detect any alien overstaying their authorized admission period.
